Tab. A-4         Functions that can be used as expressions in the variable editor




A-184                                                                  A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview
Software Reference                                                                               Temporary Stacker




     acos(X)          Arc cosine of X, X being a number between –1.0 and 1.0. The result of this function is an
                      angle between 0° and +180°. If you need the value as an arc measure, you have to apply to
                      the result of the function acos(X) the rad function.

     atan(X)          Arc tangent of X, X being a number. The result of the function is an angle between –90° and
                      +90°. If you need the value as an arc measure, you have to apply to the result of the
                      function atan(X) the rad function.
                      Please note that for many calculations, it is much easier to use the function atan2(X;Y)
                      instead of function atan(X).

    atan2(Y;X)        Arc tangent of the quotient of Y/X, Y and X both being either a length or numbers without a
                      measure. The result of this function is an angle between –180° and +180°. Atan2 uses the
                      signum values of X and Y to determine the quadrant.
                      This function calculates the correct result (±90°) if X=0.
                      If you need the value as an arc measure, you have to apply to the result of the function
                      atan2(X;Y) the rad function.
                      Please note that the parameters are separated by semicolon not by comma. The reason is
                      that a comma can be used as a decimal sign which renders it useless for functions.

     acot(X)          Arc cotangent of X, X being a number. The result of the function is an angle between –90°
                      and +90°. If you need the value as an arc measure, you have to apply to the result of the
                      function acot(X) the rad function.

      sqr(X)          X squared (X²). If X is a number, the result of this function is also a number (1st dimension).
                      If X is a line, the result of this function is a surface (2nd dimension). A+W CAD Designer
                      (Shapes) supports no other dimensions.

     sqrt(X)          Square root of X, X being a number or a surface with a positive sign. The result is a positive
                      square root, i.e. a number or a line.

     exp(X)           Exponent X (eX) of base e, X being a number. The result is also a number. It may be
                      necessary to apply the function numval to the result, or convert to standard measure.

      ln(X)           Natural logarithm of X, X being a number with a positive sign. The result is also a number. It
                      may be necessary to apply the function numval to the result, or convert to standard
                      measure.

    pow(X;Y)          Exponent Y of base X (X to the Y-th power).
                      Examples: pow(2;3)=8, pow(2;0.5)=sqrt(2). X and Y have to be numbers. Only X can be
                      negative as Y is an integer. It may be necessary to apply the function numval to the result or
                      to convert to standard measure.

      int(X)          Integer part of X.
                      Example: int(2.5)=2, int(–3.8)= –3. The result is of the same type as the expression. If the
                      expression is a number with a measure, the number will be converted as described in
                      connection with numval. The integer part will be used and converted to the same type as X.

     frac(X)          Non-integer part of X.
                      Example: frac(1.5)=0.5, frac(–2.8)= –0.8. The result has the same type as the expression. If
                      the expression is a number with a measure, the number will be converted as described in
                      connection with numval. The non-integer part will be used and converted to the same type
                      as X.
                      int and frac are defined as:
                      X=int(X)+frac(X), no matter what the sign.

     floor(X)          Biggest integer part of X, £ X.

    numval(X)       Numeric value of X. The numeric value of X calculates a number acc. to the following rules:
                    If the standard measure of A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) is mm:
                    •   If X is a length, numval shows mm.
                    •   If X is a surface, numval shows m2 (square meter).
                    •   If X is a volume, numval shows m3 (cubic meter).
                    •   If X is a negative length, numval shows mm–1.
                    If the standard measure of A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) is fractional inch or decimal inch:
                    •   If X is a length, numval shows inch.
                    •   If X is a length, numval shows sft (square feet).
                    •   If X is a length, numval shows cbft (cubic feet).
                    •   If X is a length, numval shows inverted inch.
                    If you are using different measures in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes), numval shows a metric
                    value. If you enter mm, the value will be mm and if you enter inch, the value will be inch.
                    Simple numbers (without dimension) will not be converted.

                        Results depend on the settings!
                        Contours the variables of which use the expression numval, can change unex-
                        pectedly. The reason is that the result of numval depends on the setting of the
                        standard measure with regard to input and display. Contours using numval can-
                        not be simply exchanged between different A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) instal-
                        lations. You should therefore use numval only for short-lived, customized
                        solutions. For contours you want to go on using, you should only use the corre-
                        sponding basic measures.

                        Technology-related Process-
                        ing
                        The views in menu Technology allow the selection and technology-based pro-
                        cessing of the geometry created in view Product. This is where restrictions and
                        additional conditions are checked and automatically calculated if necessary.
                        Menu Technology is used to edit the created geometry for various processing
                        methods.
                        The separation of processing and the actual processing machine has two ad-
                        vantages:
                        •   A technology can be used by several machines (drilling for drills and pro-
                            cessing machines).
                        •   The user creates the end product (the machine program) step by step in a
                            logical sequence without having to handle too much information at once.
                        Menu Technology mainly comprises the following, glass-related processing
                        steps.

                            Other menu entries are possible!
                            Depending on the configuration, your system can offer more or less menus.

                     Transform Contours
                     The functions in menu Transformation allow moving, rotation, reflection, ad-
                     justing, and extension in (nearly) all views. First, select the required contours
                     and then a function in menu Transformation. The selection of contours will be
                     kept after transformation.
                     Transformed contours appear transformed in all the following views if no ex-
                     plicit dimensions forbid this. Sizes will always override transformation. Once
                     dimensioned, an inside notch will not be moved even if it is transformed in the
                     Geometry view. Sizes are effective even in the following views. Dimensioned
                     notches will keep their position in all technology views (unless other, new sizes
                     are entered).
                     Exact alignment of contours cannot be achieved by transformation and is not
                     intended either. Transformation serves for (rough) positioning. It allows to de-
                     fine whether a contour lies within or outside an external contour for instance.
                     The exact position has to be defined by means of sizes.
                     Transformation offers the following options:
                     •   Move:
                         The command Move allows to move an existing contour. Prerequisite for
                         moving is that one segment (each) of the object(s) to be moved is tagged.
                     •   Move to point zero:
                         With this command, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will move the entire con-
                         tour so that the bottom left corner lies on the zero point (0/0) of the coordi-
                         nate system.
                     •   Rotate:
                         Use this command to rotate any contour by the desired angle. The contour
                         will be rotated around the centre of gravity of the selected contour(s).
                     •   Rotate by 90°:
                         This command will rotate the selected object clockwise by 90° around its
                         centre of gravity.
                     •   Position as in:
                         This function allows to transform a contour (move, rotate, etc.) in different
                         views. All technology views are available as sub-menus. Select a view to
                         position (transform) the selected contour just like in the present view.
                     •   Reflect horizontally:
                         The selected object is reflected horizontally. Left and right will be reversed.
                         Existing, asymmetrical inside contours (e. g. a counter-sunk hole) will not
                         be reflected (turned around). Existing trim will not be reflected either.




A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview                                                              A-193
Transform Contours                                                                  Software Reference




                     •   Reflect vertically:
                         The selected object is reflected horizontally. Left and right will be reversed.
                         Existing, asymmetrical inside contours (e. g. a counter-sunk hole) will not
                         be reflected (turned around). Existing trim will not be reflected either.
                     •   Flip horizontally:
                         The selected object is reflected horizontally. Top and bottom will be re-
                         versed. Existing, asymmetrical inside contours (e. g. counter-sunk hole) or
                         trim will be reversed as well.
                     •   Flip vertically:
                         The selected object is reflected vertically. Left and right will be reversed.
                         Existing, asymmetrical inside contours (e. g. counter-sunk hole) or trim will
                         be reversed as well.
                     •   Scale:
                         The selected object will be adjusted by the defined factors in X and Y direc-
                         tion, i. e. enlarged or reduced true to scale. If you enter a factor below 1,
                         the object will be reduced; otherwise, it will be enlarged. Different factors
                         for X (horizontal) and Y (vertical) are possible and will result in a controlled
                         distortion of the contour. Existing inside contours will be adjusted as well.

                         Adjustment is based on the current position!
                         Please note that the object will be changed, based on its current position.
                         If the object lies diagonally, it will be adjusted this way.
                     •   Stretch:
                         The selected object is stretched (or compressed) on both sides. This
                         means that the object is changed by the defined value, left and right (in X
                         direction) or top and bottom (in Y direction). Different entries for X (horizon-
                         tal) and Y (vertical) are valid and will result in a controlled distortion of the
                         contour. Existing inside contours will be stretched as well. Enter the re-
                         quired values in the input field.

                         Stretching is based on the current position!
                         Please note that the object will be changed, based on its current position.
                         If the object lies diagonally, it will be stretched this way.
                     •   Grouping:
                         This function is for grouping.
                          Tools, “Working with groups” on page A-432
                     •   Replace group:
                         This function serves to replace an existing (and tagged) group by another
                         group (in a separate SN file). The alignment applied to the existing group
                         will be applied to the new group as well.
                          Tools, “Creating a door and positioning the cut-outs” on page A-460

        Views
        This includes all functions that change the layout of the A+W CAD Designer
        (Shapes) screen or the visibility of certain elements.
        This menu also offers functions that allow to change the display of information.
        You can switch between sizes in inch or mm, or you can update the current
        sketch after re-dimensioning.
        Menu View offers the following functions:
        Transformation offers the following options:
        •   Show sizes:
            Function Show sizes offers the following options:
            – Show all dimensions
            – Show dimensions from this view
            – Show essential dimensions only
            – Show no dimensions
            As the first and last function are self-explanatory, we are going to describe
            only the second and third option.
            – Show dimensions from this view
                Shows only the dimensions defined in the current view. The Edgework
                view only shows the text entered there. View Inside contours will only
                show the dimensions between contours. Sizes from the Sketch view will
                be missing, which makes work easier if there are many inside contours
                to be dimensioned.
            – Show only essential dimensions
                This function omits obvious dimensions that were required for dimen-
                sioning. Obvious dimensions are for example information on parallel
                contours or segments, or right angles between those, as well as dis-
                tances between contours with a value of 0 (necessary entry for aligning
                two contours, e.g. for notches). If there are several identical sizes, only
                one will be shown.
        •   Check dimensions:
            This function is available in all views in which contours can be positioned
            (e.g. internal contours). This function allows to check whether the sizes de-
            fined for the positioned contours are sufficient, contradictory, or clear.A+W
            CAD Designer (Shapes) also checks if there is cyclic dimensioning, and is-
            sues a warning in this case. Incorrect sizes are shown in colour.

            Avoid waiting periods.
            Use this function if you have entered extensive dimensions, or if you go to
            another view. This will help to avoid long waits in which A+W CAD Designer
            (Shapes) tries to solve mathematical conflicts.

        •   Show selection:
            This function shows the tagged objects in the optimum size. This allows to
            view a small segment in maximum size and edit it, e.g. to move a point in
            view Revision.
             Tools, “Smoothing the contour” on page A-233

                     •   Internal contours:

                     •   Execute corners when cutting:
                         This function allows you to suppress the execution of corner rounding and
                         corner cut-offs in the cutting process for each shape. If a glass purchase
                         order is placed and corner rounding/corner cut-offs are subsequently pro-
                         duced internally on the product, this is taken into account when generating
                         SN files. In this case, the cutting view may be used to determine the geom-
                         etry of the purchased part. Therefore, corner rounding and corner cut-offs
                         are not carried out in the cutting process. When creating SN files from Or-
                         derXML, this information is stored in the SN file.

                   Digitizing via digitizer
                   Depending on the scope of your digitizer, you can apply various digitizing
                   methods. The standard is point-by-point digitizing which every digitizer is ca-
                   pable of. There are various methods, e. g. digitizing with a magnifying glass.
                   The second and simplest way of digitizing is using a wheel (or pen). Not all of
                   the digitizers offer this function. Digitizing in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) is
                   done in view Points.


                   Additional information
                    “Digitize lite as a contour” on page A-438
                    “Digitizing via digitizer” on page A-214




A-214                                                      A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview
Tools                                                                                   The Use of Tools




                     Point-by-point digitizing
                     If you digitize point by point, you have to set the points then connect them in
                     A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) by arcs or straight lines. If you are using the
                     Streamingmode module, the latter is not necessary. You can directly go from
                     digitizing to the Geometry view. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will automati-
                     cally connect the points, forming the geometry. This method requires that you
                     have set sufficient points. Only if enough points have been set, A+W CAD De-
                     signer (Shapes) can decide if they are to form an arc or a straight line.
                     If you set the arcs and straight lines by hand, you have to obey the following
                     rules:
                     •   To set a levelling segment, you have to check which points are covered by
                         a certain segment. This means that an undefined number of points de-
                         scribe a straight line or a radius. This way, an edge of the contour can con-
                         sist of several arc segments or straight segments. If you are sure which
                         levelling segment (tool) is required, first tag the first point with the corre-
                         sponding tool, then the last point of the segment.
                     •   To set the first levelling arc or straight line, tag the first digitized point with
                         the corresponding tool and proceed in the direction of digitizing.
                     •   If the segment changes (from one arc to another, or to a straight line, or vice
                         versa), you have to omit one point between the two levelling segments to
                         calculate the transition.
                     •   When you set levelling segments, you have to enter them in digitizing se-
                         quence. You cannot set all straight lines first, then all arcs, or vice versa.

                     Digitizing by wheel
                     Digitizing by wheel is the easiest way of digitizing because the digitizer will au-
                     tomatically transfer the points to A+W CAD Designer (Shapes). You do not
                     have to connect these points by levelling segments in view Points. Points are
                     connected to form a sketch by changing to the Geometry view after you have
                     digitized the last point in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes).

                     Finish digitizing
                     To tell A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) that a contour has been completely digi-
                     tized, you have to digitized the first digitized point once more. This deselects
                     the digitizing tool. If you do not hit this point exactly, you can deselect the tool
                     by hand using <ESC>. Manual deselection should be used only if automatic
                     deselection did not work.

                         Automatic deselection shall guarantee the correct input!
                         If the automatism does not work, the shape may get out of place at digitiz-
                         ing, or there may be measuring problems with the digitizing unit.

                     Digitizing of inside contours
                     Inside contours are always digitized after the outside geometry. This means
                     that you have to digitize the external geometry first in the above-described
                     way. The digitizer tool has to be deselected after that. When you start the dig-
                     itizing tool again, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will be informed that this is a
                     new geometry.



A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview                                                                  A-215
The Use of Tools                                                                              Tools




                       Do not move the contour!
                       Please make sure that the external contour is not moved before digitizing
                       the inside contour because the inside contour may then lose its correct po-
                       sition.

                   Common internal contours (no drilling) will be treated like external geometries
                   after digitizing.

                   Digitizing of holes
                   Holes will always be digitized after the external geometry. There are 2 meth-
                   ods to digitize holes:
                   •   In the first method 4 points of the outside are digitized as crosshairs, this
                       means digitize always the opposite points one after the other.
                   •   The second method requires several digitized points on a circle. These
                       points have to be set after another. The diameter of the hole can be calcu-
                       lated correctly only if at least a quarter of the hole has been digitized.


                   Additional information
                    “Digitizing of holes” on page A-440

                   Crucial points
                   When you have digitized a contour, you can have the crucial points displayed.
                   Crucial points are points where no tangential transition exists between a line
                   and an arc, or between two arcs. These crucial points will cause messy edges
                   if a processing machine is involved. You can therefore smooth these crucial
                   points.
                    “Detecting and smoothing crucial points” on page A-445

                      point, or continuously. In the latter case, the contour is traced with a mea-
                      suring wheel which will offset the edges towards the outside.
                      With point-by-point digitizing, the exact coordinates and marked and trans-
                      ferred by means of crosshairs.
                      After continuous digitizing, a parallel shift of the contour towards the inside
                      becomes necessary to remove the divergences. This parallel shift is set
                      when installing the program. The symbol P (found at the longest segment
                      of the contour) tells you if the contour has been shifted. If necessary, you
                      can change this shift.
                   1 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon.

                      itized points will be displayed. A tone shows you that you have reached the
                      starting point. The tool will be automatically deselected. You can abort dig-
                      itizing yourself by selecting a new tool or by pressing <Esc>. You can start
                      digitizing again afterwards (e.g. for drilling, inside contours).
                   3 If you change to another view after digitizing (except Sketch), A+W CAD
                     Designer (Shapes) automatically shows the interpolated connection of all
                     points as the contour. This is the recommended way of entering a contour
                     for continuously digitized contours of a good quality (flawless edges) and
                     complex structure. Depending on the scope, the standard interpolation (all
                     digitized points will be kept) or the high-performance interpolation
                     XTREAM (reduction of points with a tolerance area and optimized transi-
                     tions between angles) will be used.
                      Point-by-point digitizing is another way of entering a contour. Individual,
                      prominent points (e. g.corners) are marked by crosshairs and are imported
                      into A+W CAD Designer (Shapes). These points can be formed into
                      straight lines and arcs by means of a special tool, to create the required
                      contour. This method is recommended for simple contours (mainly straight
                      segments, many corners, less arcs); the templates may even be damaged
                      at the edges. Digitizing will ignore these damages as only the points select-
                      ed by the user will be transmitted.

                    Connecting two segments by a tangential arc




                      After creating regression segments, this tool allows to connect two seg-

                      case for example if you want to link two arcs the extensions of which have
                      no intersection. No connecting arc will be drawn in this case. You have to
                      change the adjacent segments, e.g. by deleting them and creating the con-

                     this means that your entry is correct and the arc can be calculated correctly.

                     Virtual digitizing
                     If the add-on software Virtual Digitizing (VD) has been installed at your termi-
                     nal and if A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) has been configured accordingly, you
                     can digitize shapes without a digitizer. For details on working with the VD soft-
                     ware, please refer to the manufacturer's manual. The following elements are
                     required:
                     •   calibrated digital camera with fixed focal length
                     •   a reference size
                     •   the virtual digitizing software
                     Virtual digitizing basically works as follows:
                     •   Create a shape.
                         You can do this as usual. In some cases, it may be sufficient to take a photo
                         of the gap into which the lite shall fit, without having to create a shape. The
                         shape or gap has to be a level surface.
                     •   Define a reference size.
                         You will need a level surface onto which reference points are stuck in exact
                         distances. This surface should be at least about 75 % of the rectangular
                         shape outline.
                     •   Take a photo of the shape and the reference size.
                         Before taking the photo, put the shape onto the reference size, or place it
                         in front of it. Shape and reference size have to fit levelly, and closely. If you
                         are working with a gap, a plexiglass lite will do very well for a surface for
                         the reference points.
                     •   Edit the photo with the Virtual Digitizing software.
                     •   Transfer the computed points to A+W CAD Designer (Shapes).
                     All further work steps are identical with those following the digitizing by digitiz-
                     er.
                     The following description assumes that you have defined a shape and a refer-
                     ence size, and have taken a shot of the required contour with a calibrated cam-
                     era. The image has been saved as a *.jpg file in a directory.


                      Digitizing a photo of the contour
                     1 Start A+W CAD Designer (Shapes).
                     2 In menu File select Open. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) opens the dialog
                       Open.
                     3 Go to the directory in which the image has been saved.
                     4 Choose the file type File (*.JPG). A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) shows all
                       files of this type in the selected directory.
                     5 Click on the required file and confirm by [Open]. A+W CAD Designer
                       (Shapes) starts the program Virtual Digitizing (VD) and opens the selected
                       image.
                     6 Correct the image by means of the calibration file of the camera that has
                       been used for taking the photo.




A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview                                                                 A-227
The Use of Tools                                                                               Tools




                      Please stick to the Virtual Digitizing manual!
                      For details on the described steps, please refer to the Virtual Digitizing
                      manual.

                   7 Set the reference points.
                   8 Outline the contour (e.g. using the magnetic lasso).
                   9 Let VD find points of the contour.
                   10 Correct or complete the points on the contour
                   11 Transfer the contour points to A+W CAD Designer (Shapes). Choose the
                      corresponding functions in VD to do so.
                      A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) creates an empty file and imports the points
                      of the contour from VD into view Points.
                   This means you only have to take a photograph of the contour/shape. No dig-
                   itizer is required.

                      Virtual digitizing is a supplement!
                      Please contact A+W if you are interested in virtual digitizing.


                   Importing a contour
                   Contour files (DXF, IGES, …) can be imported from any drive or directory.
                   Please make sure that a new, empty SN file is open in view 2DImport. DXF
                   import shows the data to be imported with a layer filter. You can use this filter
                   to select and import the relevant data.
                   If the contour of DXF data is still open in one or more places, A+W CAD De-
                   signer (Shapes) will show this. There are tools for editing and closing of con-
                   tours. You can switch to the Geometry view only after the contour has been
                   closed. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will show closed contours in red.


                   Additional information

                     Creating and dimensioning of sketches
                     If you have got a shape and no electronically usable data, you can use a
                     sketch to enter the required contour data. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) does
                     not need a true-to-scale sketch. If the proportions are roughly correct, it is eas-
                     ier to dimension the whole contour however.
                     To create a drawing (geometry) from a sketch, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                     needs a minimum number of sizes. Whenever you load the function draw new
                     in the Sketch view, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will determine the geometry.
                     A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) shows the number of missing sizes (or the num-
                     ber of contradictory sizes) in the center of the view Sketch (small red figure).
                     You can determine the number of sizes required by means of the following for-
                     mula:
                       3 * number of arcs
                     + 2 * number of straight lines
                     –3
                     = number of contour sizes required

                    Labelling a segmentLabelling a segment




                      You can use this tool to add text to segments. Texts can be processing
                      notes on an edge or numbers. Based on the number of the segment, a
                      linked program can e.g. be told which segment (e.g. no. 3) requires a cut-
                      out. Segment numbers are essential for shapes.
                      You can add several captions to a segment. The first text will appear right
                      next to the segment; A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will position further text
                      outside the contour. You can position the text in the required place later on
                      if required.
                      No matter what the segment position, the text will be applied horizontally to
                      the segment. When you rotate the segment, the text will be rotated as well.
                      This tells you the position of the segment at the time the text has been add-
                      ed.
                   1 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon. The tool is e.g. available
                     in view Edgework.
                   2 Click on the segment you want to label. The segment colour changes to
                     red.
                   3 Enter the text in the input field.
                   4 Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK]. Your text now appears at the seg-
                     ment.

                      Moving a point along the contourMoving a point along
                       the contour




                        This tool is used to smooth digitized curves and is very useful for correcting
                        contours used in the field of automotive glass. With this too, you can shift
                        a point in the direction of the gradient of the selected segment. If you would
                        apply a tangent to the selected segment at the selected contour point, the
                        tangent represents the two directions in which the contour point can be
                        shifted.
                        This function can also be used to define a scaling factor to increase the ac-
                        curacy for shifting the point.
                        The scaling factor (entered in the appropriate measure) defines the length
                        by which the point will be moved if you move the cursor by 10 pixels (1 pixel
                        = 1 dot on the screen = smallest visible unit) in the corresponding direction
                        or press the keys <+> or <->. If you define a scaling factor of 0,1 for exam-
                        ple, the smallest possible change of position of the contour point will be
                        0,01 mm, matching a mouse move of one pixel. This tool is therefore opti-
                        mally suited for fine-tuning the position of the contour point.

                    Move point in any directionMove point in any direction




                   This tool is used to shift contour points. It can also be used to smooth curves.
                   In a clumsily drawn sketch, it is often easier to move a contour point than re-
                   draw the whole sketch.
                   It may happen that after digitizing, some segments show transition angles of a
                   couple of degrees although the segments are supposed to blend tangentially
                   (angles should be 0°). These undesired gradient differences between seg-
                   ments can be removed with this tool. Non-tangential segment transitions may
                   cause errors in some glass processing machines, or the machines cannot pro-
                   cess the transition at all. The two related tools will often produce more exact
                   results:
                   1 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon.
                   2 Select the contour point to be moved. Click on a segment bordering on the
                     contour point. The selected segment shall be segment no. 1 and the other,
                     adjacent segment, segment no. 2.
                      At that point you will only see the drawn elastic band (in blue).
                   3 Position the cursor anywhere on the drawing board, press the left mouse
                     key and keep pressing it. The input window will show detailed information,
                     i.e. the actual position and angles, plus other data. The blue elastic band
                     constantly shows the new course of the contour. The two blue arrows mark
                     the biggest distance between the new and the original segments.
                   4 Move the cursor, keeping the mouse key pressed. Parallel with your cursor,
                     you will automatically move the selected contour points and thus the two
                     adjacent segments. Note the angle at the selected point (<c).
                   5 Release the left mouse key if you are satisfied with the angle. You can of
                     course release the mouse key in between, reposition it and go on drawing.
                     After releasing the mouse, you can change the entries in the input window.
                     These changes will be adopted at the next mouse click (left mouse key) or
                     when you press <space> and are considered for calculation.
                   6 Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK].

                      Connecting two open, partial shapes to get a
                       closed oneConnecting two open, partial shapes to get a closed
                       one




                        This function allows to merge two open contours into a single, closed con-
                        tour. This is prerequisite for handling both parts of the contour together in
                        case of changes (reflect, rotate, etc.) to create a closed chain for the tech-
                        nologies. This function is also useful if you have digitized part of a contour,
                        and want to enter the other part as a Sketch (e.g. circular arc on a rectan-
                        gle). This tool also allows to put together two parts of a contour which are
                        too big to be digitized in one go.
                        During the merging, the first selected contour (with the non-selected end
                        point) is put onto the corresponding end point of the second contour. Now
                        imagine a connecting line each between the two open end points of each
                        contour. The first contour will be rotated then so that the connecting lines
                        match. After that, the two selected points are matched to another to close
                        the complete contour. Shape and position of the two involved segments of
                        the first and second contour will be changed. A straight segment may be
                        turned into an arc segment for instance. The two opposite end points (non-
                        selected end) of the contours are then linked with each other without being
                        changed.

                    Move edge inwards or outwardsMove edge inwards or

                      This tool is used to move one side of a contour parallel towards the inside
                      (negative input) or the outside (positive input); the adjacent segments will
                      be shortened or extended in the given direction as required. Smoothly ad-
                      jacent segments will be moved automatically. In case of an inward shift,
                      segments may even be removed entirely if necessary. This tool is ideally
                      suited for architectural glass and for stepped IG.

                      Do not use for grinding allowances!

                        segment, you have to click on the     to a tagged segment on the icon, you have

                        itself.                               tool.
                     Fig. A-177    Dimensioning tools


                     Tagging sequence
                     To make sure that a tool produces the correct result, you have to consider
                     which point, segment or contour (e.g. drilling) you click first and second.

                     Points
                     For tools that require more than one mark, you have to mark the point to be
                     dimensioned (i.e. the point that shall change with the size entered) first, fol-
                     lowed by the point from which dimensioning shall start (which remains fixed).
                     Normally it is necessary to select 2 points for tools that define a certain dis-
                     tance. The additional segment is the reference edge. The reference edge de-
                     fines how the displayed sizes shall be aligned to the reference edge:
                     ExampleYou want to use the displayed tool. The tool shows 2 red points and
                     one red segment. This means you can define a distance between 2 points. The
                     distance between the points is not measured but a segment is defined as a ref-
                     erence edge instead. The distance of the points is defined as the distance of
                     the perpendicular of the points on the segment. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                     aligns the auxiliary line parallel to this segment (reference edge). First, mark
                     the required point, then the reference point (from where you are going to start
                     creating the dimension). Now mark the reference segment.

                        Further sizes can only refer to already dimensioned points!
                        The 2nd point (reference point) has already to be defined, thus A+W CAD
                        Designer (Shapes) can recognize a context to the complete geometry.

                     Drilling
                     When you dimension a chain of holes, please consider which hole you click on
                     first, and second. To define the distance between one hole and the next, fist




A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview                                                                  A-249
The Use of Tools                                                                                   Tools




                   click on the hole to be positioned, then on the already dimensioned hole. An
                   incorrect sequence will produce unexpected results.

                   Shapes
                   To make sure that A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) can compute shapes with
                   arcs in the Sketch view without hiccups, you should obey the following for
                   drawing and dimensioning:
                   •   Draw shapes with arcs in the Sketch view with roughly the required geom-
                       etry. The scale is not important at this stage.
                   •   Dimension the sketch in the sequence in which it has been drawn. Decide
                       whether you want to dimension it clockwise or anti-clockwise, then dimen-
                       sion the individual points.

                   Auxiliary lines
                   Complex contours may be hard to dimension. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                   makes things easier by using auxiliary lines as a reference for dimensioning.


                   Size properties
                   •   The dimensioning tools have been developed for different requirements.
                       The differences are:
                   •   Tools for dimensioning contours in the Sketch view. Allows to enter values
                       for contour calculation.
                   •   Tools for positioning finished contours. Allows to align completely calculat-
                       ed contours (e.g. cut-outs or holes).
                   •   Tools for displaying sizes. Allows to display the defined sizes.
                   Some tools can be used for dimensioning contours as well as positioning
                   them.
                   This window offers the options active, measuring, and fixed.

                       The position of the selected contour will change!
                       When you align contours, the position of the first selected contour will
                       change (red = active).

                   Marking the tools

                          K         You can use this tool to compute a contour in the Sketch view.

                          P         This tool is used to align contours (in the technology views and in
                                    the Inside contours view.

                         KP         This tool is used for computing and positioning contours.

                          M         This tool should only be used for measuring.

                      Dimensioning X and Y coordinates of a segment

                       coordinates of a segment end point in relation to another




                        You can use this tool to enter the relative coordinates of a contour point.
                        Relative coordinates are distances in X and Y direction which refer to a pre-
                        viously selected contour point.

                        Please avoid dimensioning based on coordinates!
                        If you are using this tool for dimensioning, you have to be sure that the con-
                        tour will not be turned around later on. Sizes referring to the coordinate sys-
                        tem will change their contour when they are turned as the coordinate
                        system (reference system) is not turned as well. Please use other dimen-
                        sioning tools if the contour is going to be turned around later.

                            two selected points.

                            – negative value: distance to the left
                        •   The Y value defines the vertical distance (Y direction) between the two
                            selected points.
                            – positive value: distance upwards
                            – negative value: distance downwards

                       shown in red.

                     4 Allocate a property to the size (active, measuring, fixed).
                     5 For active dimensioning, enter the horizontal (X value) and vertical (Y val-
                       ue) distance between the selected contour points.

                    Dimensioning X and Y coordinates of a segment
                     end pointDimensioning X and Y coordinates of a segment end
                     point




                      This tool serves to define the absolute coordinates of a contour point. Ab-
                      solute coordinates are distances in X and Y direction which refer to the or-
                      igin (zero point) of the coordinate intersection.
                      An X value defines the horizontal distance between a point and the zero
                      point. If this point lies right from the zero point, the value is positive. If it lies
                      to the left, the value is negative and has to be entered with a minus sign.
                      The Y value of a point defines the vertical distance from the zero point. If
                      the contour point lies above the zero point, it is positive. If it lies below the
                      zero point, it is negative and has to be entered with a minus sign.

                      Please avoid dimensioning based on coordinates!
                      If you are using this tool for dimensioning, you have to be sure that the con-
                      tour will not be turned around later on. Sizes referring to the coordinate sys-
                      tem will change their contour when they are turned as the coordinate
                      system (reference system) is not turned as well. Please use other dimen-
                      sioning tools if the contour is going to be turned around later.

                   1 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon.
                   2 Tag the contour point the coordinates of which you want to determine. This
                     will be shown in red.
                   3 Allocate a property to the size (active, measuring, fixed).
                   4 For active dimensioning, enter the horizontal distance (X value) and the
                     vertical distance (Y value) of the selected contour point from the zero point.
                   5 Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK].

                      Connect a segment smoothly Connect a segment
                       smoothly




                        This tool allows to define a tangential transition between two segments.
                        This means, the starting gradient of the following segment is the same as
                        the end gradient of the previous segment. The gradient difference of the
                        common contour point is thus zero.
                     1 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon.
                     2 Choose the two segments that shall be tangentially connected. The first be-
                       comes red and the second green.
                     3 If required, you can define a property for the transition (active, measuring,
                       fixed).
                     4 Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK]. The selected tangential transition
                       will be calculated and displayed on the drawing board.

                        Add edgework
                        If you add edgework (or a common edge shift) to a segment with tangen-
                        tially connected segments, this will be applied to the adjacent segments as
                        well.

                    Dimensioning the smooth transition between two arcs of the same
                     radius




                      Determining a smooth transition between two arcs means that the change
                      of angle at the common end point of the two arcs is zero. This option makes
                      sense if you have to create an arc with an aperture of more than 180°.
                      Since an arc has a maximum aperture of 180° when it is created, you have
                      to create a circle with a bigger aperture from two such segments. These
                      two segments are linked with this tool which creates a tangent relation be-
                      tween the two arcs and sets the same value for the two radii.
                   1 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon.
                   2 Tag the two arcs to be equalized. The first is shown in red and the second,
                     in green.

                    Manual input of a new drilled hole




                      This option allows to define a drilled hole in a completely dimensioned con-
                      tour. There are two ways of defining the position of the drilled hole: You can
                      either enter the exact coordinates of the center of the hole, or you ignore
                      these coordinates and define just the hole diameter at first. The inside con-
                      tour will be aligned during the next steps (e.g. towards the outside contour).
                   1 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon.
                   2 Click the left mouse key on roughly the required center of the hole or enter
                     the exact X and Y coordinates in the fields x and y. The colour of the hole
                     temporarily changes to light grey.
                   3 Enter the hole diameter.
                   4 Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK]. The selected hole will be created
                     and eventually appears in the segment colour (usually black). The diameter
                     of the hole appears next to it.

                      Holes can be displayed with or without text!
                      If you do not want any text displayed at the hole, you can delete it. You can
                      also use the text tool Entering the hole diameter to add any text to the hole.
                      Once deleted, the hole diameter can be added again by means of the tool
                      Entering the hole diameter.

                    Convert drill hole to countersunk hole




                      Since the DXF format has no default description of countersunk hole, it was
                      only possible to import circles either as simple drilling or as countersunk
                      hole. With this tool it is now possible to convert an imported drill hole to a
                      countersunk hole. There are two variants: the first determines the counter-
                      sunk via the its diameter and the second determines the countersunk via
                      the depth. Which one is the active is set in the configuration file
                      (Sn.ini).(Switch DrillholeToCounterBoreByDiameter in section User, value1
                      (default or 0 for input via diameter or depth). This tool is available in view
                      DXF Import.
                   1 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon.
                   2 Select the drilling(s) you want to convert.
                   3 Enter the necessary values. Depending on the variant these are:
                      •    d: Central diameter.
                      •    d1: Diameter of upper hole.
                      •    d2: Diameter of lower hole.
                      •    <1 and <2: Side angles of the hole in d1 and d2.
                      or
                      •    d: Central diameter.
                      •    t1: Depth of upper hole.
                      •    t2: Depth of lower hole.
                      •    <1 and <2: Side angles of the hole in d1 and d2.
                   4 Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK]. The drilling now appears on the
                     lite.

                      Use this tool to enter a countersunk hole with any side angle. A+W CAD
                      Designer (Shapes) calculates the sinking diameter by means of diameters
                      d1 and d2. This tool is available in view Inside contours and in machine-
                      related views.
                   1 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon.
                   2 Click onto the surface on which the hole shall be drilled.
                   3 Enter the necessary values:
                      •    x and y: Position of the hole.

                     Tools for processing inside contours
                     Cut-outs and holes are inside contours and are therefore mostly added in the
                     corresponding view. Depending on the size and template, cut-outs and holes
                     can already be entered when digitizing the shapes or creating the sketch.


                     Cut-outs as separate files
                     A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) allows to define simple (rectangles and arcs) or
                     complex cut-outs. Complex cut-outs can be sketched as a separate geometry
                     beforehand and saved as a SN file, or can be created in a separate file. If you
                     save the cut-outs in a separate file, you can use them again whenever re-
                     quired. The geometry of cut-outs can be created in the same way as a com-
                     mon external geometry (has to be a closed contour). Cut-outs saved in a
                     separate file can be loaded into the corresponding SN file.


                     Cutting cut-outs and holes
                     Inside contours (cut-outs and holes) and edge cut-outs are cut only if they are
                     visible in the Cutting view. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) terminals are usually
                     configured (agreed with the customer) to hide inside contours in the Cutting
                     view. You can show them here, however. Edge cut-outs cannot be automati-
                     cally hidden this way. They can be quite easily removed manually though.


                     Cut-out macros
                     A cut-out macro is a file containing a group of cut-outs and drill holes. These
                     processing steps are necessary for example to fix a certain fitting to the lite.
                     Typically, this is a cut-out, perhaps with one or more drill holes. There may be
                     only drillings. This SN file can be added to other files (which e.g. define a glass
                     door) later (even several times). If the macro is inserted via the SN-API (e.g.
                     through A+W Business), then the processings must absolutely be grouped
                     and provided with a reference point. This reference point will be used for po-
                     sitioning.
                     The following steps are necessary to create a cut-out macro:
                     •   Creating shapes and drill holes
                     •   Grouping and defining the reference point




A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview                                                               A-317
The Use of Tools                                                                               Tools




                   Creating shapes and drill holes
                   The shapes are either adopted from DXF data which may be provided by the
                   fittings supplier for example. If no such data are available, the cut-outs have to
                   be sketched in the Sketch view. Frequently (in case of edge cut-outs), these
                   cut-outs are symmetrical. We recommend to sketch just one half of the cut-out,
                   and reflect in in the Geometry view. The drill holes should be added and di-
                   mensioned in the Internal contours view.




                   Grouping and defining the reference point
                   Grouping joins the cut-outs and drill holes in a unit which can be added to the
                   external geometry. When the shape is moved or turned, all elements of this
                   unit will change their positions together, i.e. the distances and relations be-
                   tween them will be kept.
                   Grouping should be done in the Internal contours view. Use the mouse to mark
                   all drill holes plus one segment of the cut-out (if applicable).




A-318                                                     A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview
Tools                                                                               The Use of Tools




                     Select menu Transform > Group. An input window appears in which more op-
                     tions can be defined. These options apply to the edges of the grouping rectan-
                     gle and the position of the reference point.
                     The reference point is (for the time being) a corner of the grouping rectangle.
                     If the unit is added by means of the ERP system A+W Business this point will
                     be positioned on the edge of the external geometry. Additionally, the distance
                     from one end of this segment is defined. This determines the position of the
                     reference point clearly. Then, it is possible that the grouping rectangle is
                     turned so that the edge on which the reference point lies falls together with the
                     exterior edge. If the grouping rectangle is outside the glass contour, it will be
                     reflected as well. This way, just one macro has to be created for processing
                     steps which may exist in two, reflected versions.

                   Grouping is done in the following way:
                   Select the edge of the grouping rectangle where the processing steps are po-
                   sitioned on the external edge (...) . Select one of the two corners as the refer-
                   ence point. Define the distance of the grouping rectangle on this edge so that
                   the processing steps are correctly positioned when they are added: for a cut-
                   out, the edge will therefore usually have a width of 0. If the macro includes only
                   drill holes, the edge is the distance between drill holes and external geometry
                   (i.e. the distance between the drill hole centers and the external geometry, mi-
                   nus drilling radius).

                     Define cut-outs
                     The tools for defining cut-outs come in two types:
                     •   One type will only position the cut-out. This allows to handle the cut-out as
                         a BOM element. The geometry of the original shape will not be changed;
                         the shape can be recognized even if it shows additional cut-outs.
                     •   The other type will merge cut-out and contour. Automatic shape recognition

                    Positioning complex cut-outs




                      Complex cut-outs consisting of several lines and arcs (e.g. for swing door
                      fittings) can be created as separate SN files, to be added and aligned later.
                      This tool is used to position a cut-out in the required distance and alignment
                      at the appropriate edge. The tool is available in view Inside contours. Cut-
                      outs are always positioned inside the contour.
                   1 Enter the cut-out to be added to the contour in your SN file.

                      Use grouping rectangles!
                      If you are using several inside contours forming a unit (e.g. a cut-out and a
                      drilled hole which belong to the same fitting), you should group them.
                      Grouped inside contours are surrounded by a grouping rectangle by which
                      they can be aligned together at the outside contour.
                      Only grouped cut-outs have the same direction and can be aligned (dimen-
                      sioned) together. You can replace a group by another, keeping the sizes.

                   2 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon.
                   3 Tag a segment of the cut-out. Choose the segment at the cut-out you want
                     to align with a segment of your lite. Click near the segment end in the di-
                     rection in which the cut-out shall be aligned. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                     will turn the segment into a red arrow.
                   4 Tag the segment where the cut-out shall be positioned. Click near the seg-
                     ment end in the direction in which the cut-out shall be aligned. A+W CAD
                     Designer (Shapes) will change the segment into a green arrow. The cut-out
                     will be turned or reflected later so that both arrows point into the same di-
                     rection.
                   5 Enter the necessary values:
                      •   D1: Parallel distance between the two tagged segments.
                      •   D2: Distance between segment end at the cut-out and the neighboring
                          segment of the outside contour.
                      •   R1: Radius (in direction of the arrow) in which the cut-out shall meet the
                          outside edge.
                      •   R2: Radius (opposite direction of arrow) in which the cut-out shall meet
                          the outside edge.
                      •   X >> K: Cut off overlapping cut-out contour at the contour edge: If you
                          align the cut-out with the edge so that the cut-out overlaps the contour
                          edge, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will automatically cut off the cut-out
                          at the contour edge.
                   6 Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK]. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will
                     calculate and display the new position of the cut-out.

                      This tool is used to halve a segment. This tool can be applied to a segment

                      of the new segments can be selected via the tool PLACEREC to create di-
                      mensions with regard to the new point. Especially for symmetrical cut-outs,

                     drawing board.

                     calculates the half and shows it with a point.

                     Tools for surfaces
                     Below you will find the tools available for surface treatment.


                     Enter surface treatments
                     The procedure of entering surface treatments is made in three or four steps:
                     1 For the processing mark a rectangle area on the glass
                     2 Position this area on the glass
                     3 Specify the processing type.
                     4 Specify the level or the part the processing shall be made on. If your SN file
                       does not contain a BOM you will get in step 3 a selection Top/Bottom/Both
                       sides. For SN files with BOMs (e.g. for LAMI or IG) this will be made in a
                       separate step via the menu item Processing > Edit BOM (Alt+B). (See ...)

                    Satellite for free breaking




                      During the manufacturing of auto glass lites, one of the important tasks is
                      to break complex forms quickly and safely. In the past, breakage templates
                      were used underneath the glass for this purpose. The breakage templates
                      were slightly larger than the cut shape. The breakout wheel rolled largely
                      parallel to the cutting shape. Thanks to the lever effect between breakage
                      template, weight of the glass, and force of the breakout wheel, the cut was
                      broken.
                      In particular, for small quantities, the manufacturing of breakage templates
                      is unreasonably expensive.
                      This tool is a free satellite that provides the counter-force required from be-
                      low the transport belt. In the cutting code, the coordinates for both tools are
                      transmitted per movement command.
                      The tool is available in the Breakout view. In order to be able to use the tool,
                      the following prerequisites must be fulfilled in A+W CAD Designer
                      (Shapes):
                      •   The auxiliary cuts for breakout are present
                      •   The breakage path is generated
                      •   Additional paths for the satellites are generated. These paths are creat-
                          ed like breakage paths (e.g. with the AUTOBRK tool). Thanks to the
                          now subsequent marking with the SATELLITE tool, they are interpreted
                          as path information for movement of the satellite.
                      By using the SATELLITE tool, one position on the breakage path is syn-
                      chronized with one position on the satellite path. If the breakage tool is on
                      the marked point of the breakage path, the satellite should be at the corre-
                      sponding point on the satellite path. Thanks to the two-time use of the tool,
                      a section of the breakage path can thus be synchronized with a section of
                      the satellite path.
                   1 Select the SATELLITE tool to synchronize the breakage path and the sat-
                     ellite path.



A-358                                                       A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview
Tools                                                                                The Use of Tools




                     2 First click a point on the breakage path to mark a position of the breakage
                       tool. It is shown as a red dot.
                     3 Then click a point on the satellite path to mark a position of the satellite. It
                       is shown as a red dot. With the cuts 2 and 3 it is ensured that the satellite
                       and breakage tool are at the selected point at the same time.
                     4 Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK]. The breakage path and the sat-
                       ellite path are connected at the start with a dotted line and the satellite path
                       is shown in green.
                     5 Repeat steps 2, 3, and 4 to determine an end point for the synchronization.
                       The starting and end point of the satellite path can match; in this case, the
                       satellite will not move on this section (fixed satellite).
                     6 Repeat steps 2 to 5 to synchronize the movement of breakage tool and sat-
                       ellite on several sections.
                        The breakage sequence arises due to the starting points on the breakage
                        paths. The sequence for the satellite path arises through the synchroniza-
                        tion information stored with the SATELLITE tool. Therefore, no starting
                        points are set on the satellite path.

                    Adding a loop to a corner




                      Some CNC cutting machines have an offset cutting wheel. The cutting
                      wheel is positioned a little behind the rotation axis. When the machine
                      moves the axis around a corner, the cutting wheel lags behind and rounds
                      off the corner with a radius that approximately matches the distance be-
                      tween suspension axis and cutting wheel. You can avoid this rounding by
                      moving the offset wheel in a loop the radius of which is at least one sledge
                      length (we recommend to measure this generously to avoid the offset
                      wheel being turned on the spot which will wear the wheel out prematurely).
                   1 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon.
                   2 Click on the required end point. This will be shown in red.
                   3 Enter the radius of the loop.
                   4 Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK]. The two segments involved will
                     be extended and connected by two arcs.

                     the segment where the grinding should end. The segment turns green and
                     the grinding direction is now indicated by an arrow pointing at the segment.

                      (): enable this field in order to grind along the entire contour.

                      rather starting at the value input as distance. For the second grinding,

                      this edge.

                     are now marked with arrows.

                    Entering an automatic breakout path for a contour




                      This tool serves to define an automatic breakout path that can be followed
                      by a machine with a CNC controlled breakout tool. This is only possible in
                      the Breakout view. All segments entered in this view automatically belong
                      to the breakout path and will be shown in a different colour (usually violet).
                      The automatic breakout path is a copy of the original contour. It appears as
                      a parallel, moved toward the outside by distance P. The second input value,
                      /, is the distance by which the auxiliary cuts on the contour shall be skipped.
                   1 Choose the tool. To do this, click on the icon.

                     path.

                   4 Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK].

                      gle. If this is not the case, the system cannot create the breakout path; an
                      acoustic signal will alert the user.

                        cally deselected or if the defined starting points are deleted again after se-

                        The machine axis serves to define the center of the contour and - possibly
                        - for positioning the stops.
                        There are three types of machine axes:
                        •   The simple machine axis just defines the center of the contour.
                        •   The machine axis with two stops has an axis that contains two stops that
                            can be adjusted in the same direction. The machine axis (e.g. for a PSM
                            with stopper positioning) includes an additional axis that contains two
                            stops that can be adjusted in the same direction (from release 3.10).
                        •   The machine axis with three stops (e.g. for a TAC grinder) includes
                            three stops on a concentric circle (from release 3.14).
                     1 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon.
                     2 Possible procedures:
                        •   Automatic positioning of the machine axis (there must be just one con-
                            tour): Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK]. The machine axis will

                          be positioned in the center of the smallest surrounding rectangle of this

                          the center of the machine axis on the defined point.
                      Depending on the type of axis, the stops can be allocated to the stopper

                    Positioning a contour against stops




                      This tool is used to position the stops of the grinding machine (e.g. PSM)
                      against the contour. The position of the contour in relation to the center of
                      the PSM axis will remain the same in all the following views. If you are using
                      a double PSM, you will need an additional tool to align the second lite:

                      Requires the graphic display of PSM stops!
                      Prerequisite for this tool is that there is a machine axis that allows the
                      graphic display of the PSM stops. The necessary settings are made when
                      the system is installed by A+W.

                      Positioning the stops requires the following steps:
                   1 Click on the center of the PSM axis on the drawing board. The PSM axis is
                     shown in red.
                   2 Zoom down the sketch until you can see the PSM stops.
                   3 Enter the positions of the stops so that the stops touch the contour when
                     moved.
                   4 Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK].
                   5 Choose the tool. Click on the corresponding icon.
                   6 Tag a segment on the contour. It appears in red.
                   7 Tag the PSM center. It turns green, as do the stops.
                   8 Confirm your entry by <ENTER> or [OK]. If the stops are not moved against
                     the contour, you have to set the stops again as described in step 3.
                      A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will move the stops towards the contour until
                      one of them touches the contour. After that, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                      turns the contour so that the second stop also touches the contour. Finally,
                      A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) moves the third stop (from left to right, de-
                      pending on the configuration) to touch the contour.

                    Setting checkpoints by distance




                      Use this tool to define a checkpoint based on an existing point. This tool is
                      normally available in the Revision view.
                   1 First select the size tool and tag the point where measuring shall start.
                   2 Tag a second point in the direction of measuring.

                     want to set more checkpoints, you can use an existing checkpoint as a ref-
                     erence point.

                     for "clockwise" and a negative entry, "anti-clockwise". The distance is not
                     the shortest distance from the starting point but the distance along the
                     glass contour.

                     culated and appears on the contour.

                   cessing steps, often for small quantities only. This requires good drawings
