Tools                                                                                 General operation




                     General operation
                     For every menu function (e.g. Edit, Transform) you have to select the corre-
                     sponding contour first. For functions in menu Edit you have to choose the con-
                     tour to be edited (or individual segments).
                     If you want to use a tool from the tool bar, selection works the other way round.
                     First, select the required tool, then click on a suitable point on the drawing
                     board to apply the tool.

                        Performing functions and applying tools
                        Please follow the different procedures for the individual tools and functions
                        in the menus! First select the tool, then the object, but first select the object,
                        then the function.

                     Tools can execute a processing step in the required place. In case of menu
                     functions such as Edit, Transform, etc. you have to select both the object (seg-
                     ment, contour) for the operation and the action itself (how far it shall be moved
                     or rotated, etc.). The first icon on any tool bar is the cursor. Select it to termi-
                     nate or abort the previous function. The cursor is used to choose contour ele-
                     ments (e.g. for editing, transformation).


                     Elastic band
                     The elastic band appears as a blue line on screen, and can be used for mea-
                     suring and drawing.


                      Measuring with the elastic band
                     1 Position the point of the cursor in the place from which measurement shall
                       start.
                     2 Press the left mouse key and at the same time move the mouse along the
                       line you want to measure.
                     3 Release the left mouse key at the end point. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                       will create a blue X at the start and at the end of the line, and shows the
                       measuring results in the input window.


                     Additional information
                      “Enter a new line with the elastic bandEnter a new line with the elastic band” on
                       page A-230
                      “Enter new arc with the elastic bandEnter new arc with the elastic band” on
                       page A-231



                     Zoom (magnifier)
                     The tool bar offers two magnifier icons, one with a plus sign and another with
                     a minus sign. Click on those to enlarge (+) or reduce (–) the visible section.
                     The following options allow to show the drawing in different sizes:


A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview                                                                 A-419
General operation                                                                              Tools




                    •   Show optimum size
                    •   Step-by-step zooming down
                    •   Step-by-step zooming up
                    •   Enlarge section

                     Show optimum size
                        This means that A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will show all objects of a
                        drawing, using all of the available space.
                    1 Move the cursor to the [+] magnifier.
                    2 Press the left and the right key at the same time.
                      A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will show all objects in optimum size.


                     Show segment in optimum size
                    1 Tag the segment to be shown in optimum size by clicking on it. Click on the
                      first segment.
                      A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will show the tagged segment in red.
                    2 Move the cursor to the (-) magnifier.
                    3 Press the left and the right key at the same time.
                      A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will enlarge the tagged segment to fit onto
                      the whole screen.

                        All tagged segments will be enlarged!
                        You can choose several segments to enlarge them to optimum size.


                     Zoom down view step by step
                    1 Click on the [–] magnifier.
                      A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will scale down the objects, starting from the
                      center of the drawing board. Please note that A+W CAD Designer
                      (Shapes) will adapt the lettering of the rulers on the edge of the screen.
                        To scale down the drawing in a certain place, proceed as follows:
                    2 Click on the [–] magnifier and press the mouse key.
                    3 Move the magnifier icon (still keeping the mouse key pressed) to the point
                      which shall be the center of scaling down.
                    4 Release the mouse key. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will scale the view
                      one step down.
                    5 Repeat this step until the drawing has reached the required size.


                     Zoom up view step by step
                    1 Click on the [+] magnifier. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will enlarge the ob-

                     Open File
                        This function loads an existing contour saved in a *.sn file into the working
                        memory.
                    1 Select File > Open.
                    2 Enter a file name:
                        •   Enter the file name in field File name (with or without suffix) or
                        •   click on a file.
                            You can set the file type in field File type. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                            allows various graphic formats as suffixes.
                            Combo box Search in can be used to go to the required directory.
                    3 Confirm your selection by <ENTER> or [OK]. The selected contour will be
                      loaded and displayed on screen. The corresponding file name appears in
                      the program header.
                        To leave the dialog without an action, use [ABORT]. This brings you back
                        to A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) where you can resume your work.

                        Available languages
                        The dialog box language depends on the Windows version installed on
                        your computer.

                        Several drawings can be open at the same time.


                     Save file
                        Use this dialog box to enter a file name for saving the file. You do not have
                        to enter a suffix; this is done by the program. If you have chosen an existing
                        file name, the program will ask you if you want to override this file.

                        Save the file by a new name!
                        Quite often you will load a drawing to use it as a basis for creating a new
                        contour. To prevent losing the original file by overriding it, we recommend
                        to save it by a new name before editing. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) re-
                        members the last directory used for saving. This may differ from the direc-
                        tory you have used to open the file. This reduces the danger of
                        unintentional overriding a contour (e.g. planned to use as a pattern) when
                        saving (the contour dimensioned for production).

                      Move contour
                     1 Activate the arrow (cursor) by clicking on the corresponding icon.
                     2 Use the mouse to select a segment of the object to be moved.
                     3 Open the Transform menu and select the option Move. A rectangular frame
                       appears around the object to be moved; the entire object is tagged.
                     4 Click the left mouse key anywhere on the drawing board and keep pressing
                       the mouse key.
                     5 Still pressing the mouse key, move the mouse the required distance in the
                       corresponding direction (the elastic band appears).
                     6 Release the mouse key when you have reached the point in question.
                       The object will be moved the length of the elastic band in the corresponding
                       direction, to be redrawn. The length of the shift is displayed in the input win-
                       dow while the mouse is being moved.

                     1 Activate the arrow (cursor) by clicking on the corresponding icon.
                     2 Use the mouse to select a segment of the object to be rotated.
                     3 Open the Transform menu and select the option Rotate. A rectangular
                       frame appears around the object to be rotated, and the entire object is
                       tagged.
                     4 Click the left mouse key anywhere on the drawing board, and keep press-
                       ing the key.

                    Working with groups
                    Apart from choosing an individual element, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) al-
                    lows to select groups. A group if a number of elements that are edited (copy,
                    move, delete, align, or replace) together. The following steps are described be-
                    low:The following steps are described below:
                    •   “Grouping of elements” on page A-432
                    •   “Add elements to a group” on page A-433

                     Grouping of elements
                    1 Tag several elements. Keep pressing <Ctrl> while clicking on the elements
                      (segments, drilling) to be grouped. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) adds new
                      elements to the tagged objects and shows them in red. If you do not move
                      the mouse while pressing the left or right mouse key, the next or previous
                      segments will be added to the tagged segments.
                        Some tools require the selection of several elements right away; you do not
                        have to press the key in this case. If several elements have been selected,
                        addition of elements remains active even if you release the key.
                        Extension of the selection remains active until you click on another tool.
                        Click on the arrow (cursor) to cancel an existing tag.
                    2 In menu Transform, select option Group. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                      shows the following settings in the input window:

                        Option        Meaning

                        [_]           With this setting, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) creates a vertical
                                      grouping rectangle.

                        /_/           With this setting, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) creates a group
                                      the grouping rectangle of which is parallel to one of the
                                      segments of the group of contours. Rotate the contours around
                                      the x axis to create, a rotated grouping rectangle.

                        min           With this setting, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) creates a
                                      minimum grouping rectangle.

                        fix           After a group has been fixed, you cannot add further elements
                                      (contours).

                        RefP          Defines the reference edge for the grouping rectangle. If you
                                      want to align the group at another element, the alignment refers
                                      to the defined side. Valid entries are:
                                      • 1: bottom edge
                                      • 2: right edge
                                      • 3: top edge
                                      • 4: left edge
                                       “Positioning complex cut-outs” on page A-326

                  Digitize lite as a contour
                  The digitizing of contours consists of the following steps:
                  •   Digitizing via digitizer
                  •   Virtual digitizing
                  •   Post-processing in CAD Designer

                  Digitizing via digitizer
                  You can apply various digitizing methods, depending on the digitizer you are
                  using. The standard is point-by-point digitizing which every digitizer is capable
                  of. You can use a magnifier or a pen for digitizing. The result is the same. The
                  second and easier way of digitizing is by means of a digitizing wheel. Not all
                  of the digitizers offer this function. Digitizing in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                  is done in view Points. No matter which method you choose, the basic proce-
                  dure is the same in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes).
                  The following steps are described below:
                  •   Digitizing an external contour by wheel
                  •   Digitizing an external contour with pen or magnifier
                  •   Digitizing inside contours
                  •   Digitizing of holes


                   Digitizing an external contour by wheel
                  1 Go to view Points.
                  2 Tag the digitizing tool.




                  3 Go to the digitizer and start digitizing the contour.
                      Point the wheel at the starting point and press Start. The digitizer now
                      sends the coordinates of the digitizing wheel in regular intervals to A+W
                      CAD Designer (Shapes). Surround the contour. Interrupt the transfer of
                      points should you reach disrupting points (e.g. fixings). After an interrupt,
                      resume digitizing at a suitable point in the same direction until you reach
                      the starting point. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will realize that you have
                      surrounded the contour, and will disable the selected tool.
                  4 Enter the corresponding inside contour if applicable.
                  5 After you have entered the contour completely, go to view Geometry. A+W
                    CAD Designer (Shapes) will interpolate the points into straight lines and ra-
                    dii.
                      A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) now corrects the position of the points
                      around the radius of the digitizing wheel. After this correction, A+W CAD
                      Designer (Shapes) will show a P at the edge. If you click on the P, A+W

                  Post-processing in CAD Designer
                  When a contour has been digitized or imported, it still needs to be optimized
                  for being processed by the various machines. These corrections are described
                  below:
                  •   Manual positioning of adjustment arcs and lines
                  •   Detecting and smoothing crucial points
                  •   Align contour


                   Manual positioning of adjustment arcs and lines
                      The following description is based on the assumption that you have digi-
                      tized a contour in view Points and that the digitizing tools has been dese-
                      lected afterwards.

                      Starting point for digitizing
                      When setting adjustment arcs and lines manually, you have to start with the
                      point that has been digitized first (starting point). Note this point in view
                      Points. Starting the adjustment arcs/lines at another point may cause pro-
                      gram errors.

                      Proceed as follows to surround the digitized points of a contour by the re-
                      quired adjustment arcs and lines.
                  1 Identify the starting point where digitizing has begun.
                  2 Choose the appropriate tool (adjustment arc or line).




                  3 Click on the start point. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) shows this point in
                    red.
                  4 Search the point where the adjustment arc/line shall end (in the direction of
                    digitizing), and click on it. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) shows this point in
                    green; all previous points appear in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) red.
                  5 Press [OK].
                  6 Omit one point (two spaces) between two arcs. Leave one space between
                    a straight line and an arc. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) needs this space
                    to calculate the adjustment between the segments.
                  7 Select the appropriate tool (adjustment arc or line) and click on the next us-
                    able point (after an omitted point or a space).

                      Change the tool!
                      To apply a straight line after an arc (or vice versa), you have to change the
                      tool. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) uses different algorithms for internal
                      calculation.

                        Stick to a logical sequence even if this means changing the tool several
                        times. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will produce incorrect results if you
                        apply all the straight lines first, then all arcs.

                     8 Repeat the steps 3 to 6 until you have reached the last point. You have to
                       omit this if it lies between two arcs.
                     9 Go to the Geometry view. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) calculates the seg-
                       ments and shows the resulting contour.
                        Depending on how you have positioned the adjustment arcs and lines,
                        there may be rounded corners still which need sharpening or crucial points

                      Detecting and smoothing crucial points
                        Crucial points are segments or points on a contour that cannot be produced
                        or processed the way they are. Crucial points are points where no tangen-
                        tial transition (0°) exists between a line and an arc, or between two arcs.
                        These crucial points will produce jagged edges if processed by a machine,
                        or will slow down the cutting process. Crucial points can be defined in
                        sn.ini.
                        Using the tools for smoothing a contour, you can move the crucial point until
                        a tangential angle of 0° or close to 0° has been achieved. The contour will
                        be minimally reduced or extended at that point.
                     1 Go to the Geometry view.
                     2 In menu View > Settings > Show crucial points enable the item Mark crucial
                       points in geometry and revision.
                        A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) now marks the crucial points on the contour
                        with blue arrows.
                     3 Click on a segment at a crucial point. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) marks
                       the segment in red and numbers the ends as 1 and 2. In the input window,
                       A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) shows information on the segment and the
                       angles of the points 1 and 2.
                     4 Click on the tool you want to use to move the point at the crucial point.




                        The arrow shows the tool icon.

                  5 Click the tool on the crucial point you want to remove. A+W CAD Designer
                    (Shapes) shows step length D in the input window.
                     If you have selected the tool Move point in any direction, you can move the
                     tagged point by means of the mouse, keeping the left mouse key pressed.
                     A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) permanently shows the actual result in the
                     input window. The next steps are not applicable with this tool.
                  6 Change the step length is necessary. The step length is the distance by
                    which A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) moves the tagged point until the
                    smallest possible tangential angle has been reached. After each step
                    length, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will calculate the result.

                     Don't do too much
                     To achieve an optimum result, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) tries to
                     smooth not only the selected point, but also the adjacent ones. If you need
                     to smooth several crucial points, we recommend to start from the middle.

                  7 Press [OK]. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) calculates the position of the
                    point in the defined direction for which the transition angle between the ad-
                    jacent segments is minimal. The new segment sequence is shown in blue.
                    A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) shows the result of the shifting in the input
                    window.

                  Working with variables
                  You can use variables for creating shapes.
                  Another field of application is the variable design of views in A+W CAD De-
                  signer (Shapes). Depending on the proportions, edges may look as if they
                  were parallel or rectangular on the printout, but are actually different. You can
                  use variables to define conditions to distort a sketch in order to show the ge-
                  ometries. The following steps are described below:
                  •   Defining conditions
                  •   Using variables in the sketch


                  Additional information
                   “Working with shapes” on page A-468


                   Defining conditions
                      Apart from variables, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) supports arithmetic ex-
                      pressions in variables.
                      Logical distinctions have to be defined by means of arithmetical means. A
                      major role plays the signum function sign(x). sign(x) has the following char-
                      acteristics:
                      •   sign(x) = 1, if x  0
                      •   sign(x) = –1, if x < 0
                      •   sign(x) – sign(-x) = 2, if x > 0
                      •   sign(x) – sign(-x) = 0, if x = 0
                      •   sign(x) – sign(-x) = –2, if x < 0
                      The signum function allows to create the following arithmetic isolation ex-
                      pressions (an isolation expression is an expression with a value of 1 if a
                      condition is fulfilled or a value of 0 if the condition is not fulfilled):

                      Condition       Isolation expression

                      x<y             0.5*(1–sign(x–y))

                      xy             0.5*(1+sign(y–x))

                      x>y             0.5*(1–sign(y–x))

                      xy             0.5*(1+sign(x–y))

                      x=y             0.5*(sign(y–x)+sign(x–y))

                      xy              1 – 0.5*(sign(y–x)+sign(x–y))

                      Tab. A-46     Isolation expressions

                      This way, f(y–x) = (sign(y–x)-sign(–(y–x))/2 applies
                      •   = 1, if y > x
                      •   = 0, if y = x
                      •   = –1, if y < x

                        The variables D1, D2, H, H1, W and W1 have to be entered (manually or
                        via transfer file).
                        The following situations may arise in this example:
                        •   The ratio of height and width (H and W) is unfavorable for a true-to-scale
                            drawing. This is the case for instance if H > 4 * W. In this case, the draw-
                            ing should not be displayed true to scale, but should be labelled correct-
                            ly.
                        •   The ratio of D2 and H or D1 and H or H1 and H is so small that it is hard
                            to see on the sketch; it has to be displayed out of proportion therefore.
                            This is the case for example if the ratio D2 and H is smaller than 1:10
                            and if the ratio of D1 or H1 and H lies below 1:20.
                        •   The total height and total width of the contour will be influenced by large
                            values for D1 or D2 to such an extent that D1 and D2 have to be con-
                            sidered for determining the size ratio.


A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview                                                              A-471
Fixed Questions                                                                                  Tools




                  2 Go to the Geometry view. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) shows the dialog
                    Edit variables. Enter the values shown in the example.
                  3 Determine the total height and width of the contour. Create the variables
                    __HTot and __WTot using the function max(x1;x2;...;xn).
                     •   __HTot = max(H;H-D2)
                     •   __WTot = max(W;W-D1)
                     Use H–D2 and W–D1 as D1 and D2 will increase the width and height if
                     their values are negative.
                  4 Determine the ratio of the contour and check if it falls below 1:4. If this is
                    the case, calculate the missing line for a ratio of 1:4. Create the following
                    variables:
                     •   __HzuW = __HTot/__WTot
                     •   __fGr4zu1 = 0.5*(1–sign(4–__HzuW))
                         This isolation expression = 1 if height : width > 4.
                     •   _DStreck = __fGr4zu1*(__HTot/4–__WTot)
                         _DStreck will be required for creating the sketch later on. Stretching is
                         necessary only if the ratio of height and width is over 4. In this case, the
                         amount missing from this ratio will be used for stretching (__HTot/4-
                         __WTot). Please obey the calculation rule, point before line ((__HTot/4)-
                         __WTot).

                     Please obey the name convention for variables!
                     For clarity's sake, we have obeyed the following rules for variable names
                     in this example: Variables starting with an underscore, have to be entered
                     in the input window. Variables starting with two underscores are used to
                     calculate interim steps (e.g. isolation expressions).

                  5 Determine the size of the vertical slant and check whether the ratio of 1:10
                    is met. If the ratio is smaller, determine the missing line for a ratio of 1:10.
                    Create the following variables:
                     •   __fD2 = 0.5*(sign(D2)–sign(–D2))
                         __fD2 is 0 if D2 = 0. If D2 > or < 0, exaggeration is called for until a ratio
                         of 1:10 is achieved.
                     •   __VerschD2 = max(H/10–abs(D2);0 mm)
                         The edge is already slanted by D2. The missing slant is thus H/10-D2.
                         Since D2 can have a negative sign, the absolute amount of D2 has to
                         be used: H/10-abs(D2). If D2 is already over H/10, this expression is
                         negative. In this case, the printout shows 0 mm so that exaggeration is
                         not required.
                     •   _SchrD2 = (–1)*__fD2*__VerschD2
                         The exaggeration sign is negative because D2 is positive towards the
                         inside.
                  6 Determine the size of the horizontal slant for D1 and check if the ratio of
                    1:20 is met. If the ratio is smaller, determine the missing line for a ratio of
                    1:20. Create the following variables:
                     •   __fD1 = 0.5*(sign(D1)–sign(–D1))

                  Define edgework
                  In connection with edgework, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) distinguishes
                  edge types and edge qualities.
                  Edge types define if an edge is a standard edge, a shape edge, or a special
                  edge. Based on this, cost calculation can be run in a linked order entry system.


                  Edge definition
                   “Defining a standard edge” on page A-416
                   “Defining an edge as an outside shape edge” on page A-417
                   “Defining an edge as an inside shape edge” on page A-417
                   “Defining an edge as a special shape edge” on page A-416
                  The edge quality defines the way in which individual or all edges of a lite shall
                  be processed (e.g. grinding, polishing, etc.). There is a multitude of possible
                  processing steps:
                   “Processing of single annealed edges” on page A-403
                   “Edgework for laminated glass/IG” on page A-410


                  Corner processing
                  Edges can be rounded or cut off. Rounded and cut?off corners can be defined
                  as common processing or as a so?called commercially rounded or cut?off cor-
                  ner.
                  The commercial rounded or cut-off edge is returned by A+W CAD Designer
                  (Shapes) to order entry via AWBroke as a BOM element. With regard to pro-
                  cessing, commercially rounded or cut-off corners do not differ from those with-
                  out BOM information.
                  For more information on corner processing, please see:
                   “Define cutting path at the corners” on page A-360

                     Interplay with other programs
                     A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) can be linked with a commercial system (order
                     entry) or a production control system. Information on a product will be imported
                     from order entry, completed in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) and returned to
                     the linked system. The following steps are described below:
                     •   Interaction with A+W Enterprise
                     •   Interaction with A+W Business
                     •   Data export


                     Interaction with A+W Enterprise
                     If you are using A+W Enterprise, you can create a file for every order item right
                     at order entry. A+W Enterprise calls this Technical order processing (TOP).
                     Prerequisite for this interplay of A+W Enterprise and A+W CAD Designer
                     (Shapes) is a complete conversion table for article numbers. A+W CAD De-
                     signer (Shapes) has to have its own name for every article. This name is called
                     SN key in A+W Enterprise.
                     A+W Enterprise TOP in connection with A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) allows
                     to create SN files based on the A+W Enterprise BOM. With A+W CAD Design-
                     er (Shapes), the user can describe complex BOM products. The file is created
                     in the background. Completed by A+W CAD Designer (Shapes), the BOM is
                     returned to A+W Enterprise.
                     There are the following options:
                     •   Linking via AWBroke
                     •   Link via SNAuto

                     Linking via AWBroke
                     (Foreground or online TOP)
                     To start A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) in A+W Enterprise, the article numbers
                     in the A+W Enterprise BOM has to be converted into a BOM with SN article
                     numbers. This is done by AWBroke. The table containing both the A+W Enter-
                     prise article numbers and the corresponding A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) ar-
                     ticle numbers can be kept in A+W Enterprise master data.
                     To be able to convert BOM information, a BOM description language has been
                     developed. A file in which a BOM is described in this language, is called BOM
                     script. The file extension is .sl.
                     For TOP, A+W Enterprise is the master system which initiates the link with
                     A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) as described below:

                     Load CAD Designer (C) To enter or edit the item via A+W CAD Designer
                     (Shapes), use the key combination <Ctrl> + <E> in the quantity field of the
                     item, or click on the Shaping/Nesting icon. A+W Enterprise now creates a de-
                     fault BOM for this item and loads AWBroke.

                     Convert BOM and start CAD Designer (D, E, F) A+W Enterprise converts
                     the default BOM by means of the allocation table. This allocation is made in
                     table snkey in the A+W Enterprise database. AWBroke accesses the default
                     BOM. AWBroke starts A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) and transfers the data of
                     the lite selected in A+W Enterprise.

                     Edit and return the item (G, H, I) Use the options A+W CAD Designer
                     (Shapes) offers for complete graphic description of the item (e.g. sizes, drilling,
                     edgework). When you have described the item, select menu Return to order
                     processing.
                     A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) saves the product description in a file. These
                     files are item-specific and belong to the order data. The file gets its name from
                     the number range contour.mfo. The name is assigned in A+W Enterprise and
                     is part of the default BOM. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) activates AWBroke
                     and releases the transfer of the resulting BOM. AWBroke thus accesses the
                     INFORMIX database via ODBC and reads the conversion table.
                     AWBroke interprets the data provided by A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) and
                     writes the result BOM. The result BOM is saved as a .sl file in the defined di-
                     rectory on the UNIX PC. AWBroke replaces the A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                     article numbers (e.g. for processing steps) by A+W Enterprise article numbers.
                     A+W Enterprise has been running in a wait loop since loading A+W CAD De-
                     signer (Shapes). As soon as the file containing the BOM has been received, it
                     updates the order data, and the user can go on entering items in A+W Enter-
                     prise. When you create another SN file for other order items in A+W Enter-
                     prise, the same file names for default BOM and return BOM (sl files) will be
                     used for the data transfer with A+W CAD Designer (Shapes). The previously
                     created files (SL files) will be overridden.

                  A+W Enterprise-Master data
                  In A+W Enterprise master data, a so-called A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                  code has to be defined for every article so that the default BOM for A+W CAD
                  Designer (Shapes) can be converted.
                  In A+W Enterprise, the A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) code allocation is de-
                  fined in Master data > Keys > Product keys > Shaping/Nesting articles.

                      Unique CAD Designer article numbers
                      A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) codes (here: CAD Designer article numbers)
                      are unique and always end with a dot < . > .

                  A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) codes have the following structure:

                  Glass
                  •   Glass codes start with a G
                  •   Followed by two numbers for the category:
                      – G01 for float
                      – G02 for toughened glass
                      – G03, G08, G09 for laminated glass
                      – G06 for IG
                  •   This is followed by any number (e.g. the A+W Enterprise article number)
                      e.g.: G02300008 "Toughened Float 8mm"
                  •   The glass code can be abbreviated: Example:
                      G02.ESG.




A-486                                                   A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview
Tools                                                                                 Fixed Questions




                     Processings
                     Edgework
                     •   Edgework code starts with a K
                     •   They are distinguished by outside edge, inside edge, outside edge of
                         shape, and inside edge of shape
                     •   The edgework code can be added, too: KG 02300008 .109. "bevelled out-
                         side edge for toughened float 8 mm"
                     •   The edgework code can be abbreviated:
                         KG 02.109., bevelled outside edge for toughened
                     Drill holes
                     •   Drill codes start with a D
                     •   Follows a three-digit type code:
                         – 101 = Standard hole
                         – 102 = counter-sunk hole, both sides
                         – 103 = counter-sunk hole, top
                         – 104 Counter-sunk hole, bottom
                     •   This is followed by two five-digit groups of numbers for the diameter in tenth
                         of a millimeter:
                         D1010200005000.
                     •   The drilling code can be abbreviated after the type:
                         D101.
                     •   A glass code can be added to the drilling code:
                         DG02300008.1010200005000.:
                         Drilling of 20 to 50 mm on toughened float 8 mm
                     •   The glass code can be abbreviated:
                         DG02.1010200005000.:
                         Drilling of 20 to 50 mm on toughened
                     Cut-outs
                     •   Cut-out codes start with an A
                     •   Follows a number defining the type of cut-out:
                         – 1 = edge cut-out
                         – 2 = corner cut-out
                         – 3 = inside cut-out;
                     •   This is followed by four (random) numbers.
                     •   These are followed by two five-digit numbers defining the length in x- and
                         y-direction: Example A100010010000080. "edge cut-out (type 1) of x=100
                         mm, y=80 mm"
                     •   You can include glass and edgework codes in this code:
                         AKG02.109.100010010000080. for edge cut-out (type 1) in TGH with pol-
                         ished edges, size x=100 mm, y=80 mm

                  Essential Restrictions
                  There are some essential restrictions with regards to TOP in connection with
                  A+W Enterprise, AWBroke, and A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) which need to
                  be taken into account:
                  •   Sub-items cannot be removed.
                      This TOP contains just one SN file per A+W Enterprise order item. This file
                      contains the geometry of all sub-items of the item (glass only). The geom-
                      etry of an individual sub-item (e.g. for a purchase order) cannot be re-
                      moved.
                  •   Glass types that cannot be handled:
                      Cut laminated glass cannot be handled by the TOP at present. The same
                      applies to stepped IG.
                  •   Processing that cannot be handled:
                      TOP with A+W Enterprise, AWBroke and A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                      does not handle the following processing steps:
                      –   Stepped IG and laminated glass
                      –   Mitres with selectable angle
                      –   Facets with angles and grinding depth
                      –   Asymmetrical notches
                      –   Fluted bevelling
                      –   Surface processing (silk screening, corroding, ...)

                      Time required
                      Compared with summarily entering processing steps in the BOM, complete
                      entry of an item via CAD requires more time. The calculating times in A+W
                      CAD Designer (Shapes) and the transfer times between A+W Enterprise
                      and A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) also slow down the input. Still, the over-
                      all process is quicker as geometric input is not necessary at production
                      scheduling.

                      Do not change the BOM afterwards!
                      After processing through A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) you should not
                      change BOM-relevant information in A+W Enterprise (such as changing
                      the glass type) as this will not be automatically amended in the SN file.
                      Should this be inevitable, you have to load A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                      again. Thus, you make sure that this additional information is saved in the
                      corresponding SN file.


                   Create SN files via AWBroke
                  1 Enter the data in the order header as usual.
                  2 Enter the order item.
                    Describe the order item as completely as possible. Enter the shape number
                    for example, and replace special articles if necessary (e.g. film layers,
                    glass) in the BOM before starting A+W CAD Designer (Shapes).
                  3 Start A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) using <Ctrl> + <E> or click on the
                    [ShapingNesting] icon.

                        AWBroke is started in the background and creates a SN file. A+W CAD De-
                        signer (Shapes) is started as well and displays the file created by AW-
                        Broke. You can use dialog Global shape data to view the information
                        transferred by A+W Enterprise.
                     4 Enter the necessary sizes, edgework, cut-outs, counter-sunk holes, and
                       holes in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes).

                        Use processing steps as BOM elements!
                        Some processing steps will blend in with the contour while others remain
                        processing steps. When you select the tools, please make sure to use tools
                        the processing of which is returned to A+W Enterprise as a BOM element.

                     5 Select File > Return to order processing.
                        A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) closes the file. AWBroke converts the added
                        and BOM-suited information and processing steps and completes the order
                        item's BOM in A+W Enterprise.

                        A+W Enterprise is waiting for information from CAD Designer!
                        While you are editing the order item in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes), A+W
                        Enterprise is waiting. You can resume working with A+W Enterprise only af-
                        ter you have completed editing in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes). If there is
                        an error in the communication between A+W Enterprise and A+W CAD De-
                        signer (Shapes) and A+W Enterprise is locked, you can use the key com-
                        bination <Ctrl> + <Del> to abort communication. No SN file will be created
                        for the item in question. You will have to repeat this step for this item.

                        Do not change CAD-relevant entries in the BOM!
                        If you try to change the A+W Enterprise BOM at that point, the system will
                        inform you that this is a CAD item. In case of CAD-relevant amendments,
                        SN file and order item would no longer match. CAD-relevant are sizes,
                        edgework, cut-outs, counter-sunk holes, and holes. To effect changes at of
                        this kind at that point, you have to start A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) once
                        more.

                     6 Enter further items in A+W Enterprise if required.
                     7 If you have to change CAD-relevant entries in the BOM, start A+W CAD
                       Designer (Shapes) again for the item in question (see Step 3).
                        The SN file belonging to the order item will be required by A+W Production

                  Requirements
                  TOP via SNAuto requires just the usual A+W Enterprise workstations. The
                  necessary equipment of the workstations depends on the valid system re-
                  quirements for A+W Enterprise. Apart from that, there has to be a special PC
                  for this purpose, equipped with Windows 2000 Professional, Windows 2000
                  Server, or Windows XP Professional, on which the SNAuto process is in-
                  stalled. The system requirements for this PC are those valid for a SNAuto serv-
                  er (available from A+W).
                  The SNAuto server must be able to address drives in the UNIX environment
                  via Samba. Alternatively, data can be exchanged via ftp.
                  To enable SNAuto to convert A+W Enterprise articles into SN article numbers,
                  the table allocating the A+W Enterprise article numbers and the corresponding
                  A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) article numbers is required (like for AWBroke).
                  These can be maintained in A+W Enterprise master data. TOP cannot be run
                  without this table.

                     Availability

                     you have already installed A+W CAD Designer (Shapes). A+W CAD Designer

                     TOP via A+W Enterprise/SNAuto and A+W Enterprise version 2.12 can be run
                     on A+W Enterprise platforms SCO and AIX. Other A+W Enterprise versions
                     do not support this type of TOP. This type of TOP is not available on other
                     UNIX versions.

                     Applicable product types
                     TOP via A+W Enterprise/SNAuto is available only for the product types listed
                     in this chapter (glass, processing, shapes). Glass types, processing types,
                     and shapes that are not listed there, cannot be handled by TOP at present.
                     Glass articles
                        TOP with A+W Enterprise/SNAuto can handle the following glass types:
                        •   Float glass, unprocessed (article 11xxxx).
                        •   Float glass, processed (article 15xxxx).
                        •   Toughened glass (article 30xxxx and 35xxxx) including simple float (ar-
                            ticle 11xxxx) or processed float (article 15xxxx).
                        •   Laminated glass consisting of float or toughened glass, consisting of the
                            previously mentioned glass types, but no cut laminated glass (article
                            40xxxx).
                        •   IG units consisting of the formerly mentioned glass types, but no
                            stepped IG (article 50xxxx).
                     Processings
                        TOP via A+W Enterprise/SNAuto can handle the following types of pro-
                        cessing:
                        •   Cylindrical (normal) drillings
                        •   Counter-sunk holes (top, bottom, both sides)
                        •   Seamed, ground, and polished edges
                        •   Definable special edges. These special edges cannot be parametrized.
                            There are 15 different types of special edges.
                     Shapes
                        TOP via A+W Enterprise/SNAuto can handle rectangles and shapes from
                        a defined shape catalog. The shape catalog can be one of those available
                        in A+W Enterprise. Only the standard shapes listed in the catalog are fea-

                        be used with SNAuto even if the customer has already got this extension
                        in A+W Enterprise.

                     Environment variables for SNAuto in A+W Enterprise
                     When you install SNAuto you can make various settings which will influence
                     your working with SNAuto. This is done by means of environment variables in
                     A+W Enterprise you can choose from the following versions when you release
                     the module:
                     •   For every item, A+W Enterprise will want to know whether a SN file shall
                         be created via SNAuto.
                     •   A+W Enterprise asks SNAuto for a SN file for every item.
                     The settings for SNAuto can be made for an individual user as well as for the
                     entire application. For details on environment variables, please contact the
                     service of A+W.


                      Create SN files via SNAuto
                         Working with SNAuto is meant for quick input of order items with CAD in-
                         formation.
                     1 Enter the data in the order header as usual.
                     2 Enter the order item. Enter the product number.
                     3 After entering the article number, A+W Enterprise will ask if you want to cre-
                       ate a SN file for this item.

                         The system will ask for the SN file only at initial input!
                         The question as to whether a SN file shall be created for this item, only ap-
                         pears at initial input. Changes will not be automatically included in the SN
                         file. Creation of a new SN file has to be initiated by the key combination
                         <Ctrl> + <N>.
                     4 Confirm this question by [Yes].
                     5 Open the BOM view by pressing <F3> in field Quantity.
                         A+W Enterprise will show the bill of material.
                     6 Complete the BOM by the necessary processing steps.
                     7 Return to the order item and open item input. A+W Enterprise displays the
                       dialog for entering the processing parameters.
                     8 Complete the necessary parameters for the processing of the lite. SNAuto
                       needs this information to crate a complete A+W CAD Designer (Shapes)
                       file.

                      Create automatic variables
                        Variables have to be entered in the following fashion in SN templates you
                        want to dimension automatically in A+W Business:
                        __XXXX_YY_ZZ
                        (2 underscores, 4 numbers, 1 underscore, 2 numbers, 1 underscore, 2
                        numbers)
                        XXXX = four-digit product number for the processing in A+W Business.
                        YY = how often does this processing step occur in the glass to be pro-
                        cessed.
                        ZZ = processing size to be analyzed.
                        To use automatic variables, proceed as follows:
                     1 Create a SN file with the required contour.
                     2 Dimension the contour using variables.
                        Use variable names acc. to pattern described above.
                     3 Enter the A+W Business product number (XXXX) in the variable.
                     4 In the variable, which of the existing processing steps (in the A+W Busi-
                       ness BOM for the glass) shall be used to preset the dimension (YY).
                     5 In the variable, define the processing parameter to be used for entering a
                       value for the variable (ZZ). The parameters will be analyzed based on the
                       processing type:
                        •   Processing type Drilling:
                            – 00 = X value hole 1
                            – 01 = Y value hole 1
                            – 02 = diameter hole 1

                  When you install machine drivers, you define the view from which the geome-
                  try shall be exported. This makes sure that the grinding machine will be sup-
                  plied with data from the Grinding view, and the drill from the Drilling view.


                  Via DXF files
                  Everyone working with CAD and sketching programs, will know DXF as the
                  standard export / import format that allows to exchange CAD files between dif-
                  ferent application programs. The DXF file contains the graphic-geometrical
                  data of the sketched objects in an internationally applied code. This informa-
                  tion can be read by every CAD program.
                  Because of its CAM elements, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) has to be able to
                  recognize and manage contour connections. Unlike for conventional CAD sys-
                  tems, segment relations are important. It is not enough for A+W CAD Designer
                  (Shapes) to manage a collection of individual segments; these segments have
                  to form a coherent contour.

                  Standard DXF
                  The DXF format contains geometrical data, i.e. it defines parameters such as
                  contour and number of sketched elements, size, colour, line thickness, drilling
                  positions, etc. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) can read and process these DXF
                  files and can also save contours in this format.
                  DXF files contain no information on machinery processes required to produce
                  the sketched element. This includes the cutting path, the breakout sequence,
                  and other information that can be entered and predefined in A+W CAD De-
                  signer (Shapes).
                  To make sure that DXF files can be read correctly by other CAD programs
                  without much editing in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes), you have to obey some
                  instructions. Example: only one line is usually drawn between two adjacent li-
                  tes although A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) needs two segments to limit the li-
                  tes. The end points of adjacent segments often do not match exactly. A+W
                  CAD Designer (Shapes) will use so-called "catch areas" in this case. If seg-
                  ment ends are within the same catch area, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) can
                  link them automatically.
                  You should follow these guidelines when you create files in a CAD program
                  and want to process the data in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes):
                  •   The contour to be imported should be complete and be the only one on a
                      DXF layer. If several contours are imported from a DXF file, each of them
                      should sit on a separate layer. Labelling, sizes, legends, etc. should be kept
                      in separate layers.
                  •   The contour to be imported has to be closed. Open contours have to be ed-
                      ited in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes).
                  •   The contour to be imported should consist of ARC-, LINE- and CIRCLE en-
                      tities. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) can import POLYLINE entities to a cer-
                      tain extent; this is best avoided however. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will


A-504                                                    A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview
Tools                                                                              Fixed Questions




                         convert SOLID- and TRACE entities into several LINE entities to be able to
                         import them. You should use CIRCLE entities only to define the position of
                         drilled holes.
                     •   The DXF header will not be interpreted. DXF files become smaller if you
                         omit the header. Importing into A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) only requires
                         the SECTION ENTITIES. This means that ARC entities cannot be entered
                         in clockwise order because this setting is defined by the variable $ANGDIR
                         in SECTION HEADER.
                     •   INSERT entities will not be expanded. This means that the entire contour
                         has to be defined in SECTION ENTITIES and cannot be constructed from
                         blocks.
                     •   The separating points of adjacent segments of a contour should match.
                     •   If several contours have to be put into a layer, you should avoid branches.
                         Otherwise, the wrong segments might be formed into a contour.
                     Basically, we recommend that the supplier of the DXF files should adapt his
                     file for the import into A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) using the above guide-
                     lines.



                     For the operator of a CNC machine, receiving the DXF file means only the start
                     of his actual work. The operator has to convert all the details of the DXF file
                     required for the processing on hand in a predefined process. He must define
                     the tools to be used as well as all processing parameters. This is how the pro-
                     cessing (CAM) program is created, to be transferred to the machine.
                     A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) offers an extended DXF, CAMDXF. This format
                     includes the machinery control information. The CAMDXF format offers the fol-
                     lowing advantages:
                     •   Controlling the machines with the processing data becomes faster, more
                         elegant, and safer.
                     •   Apart from the geometrical data, CAMDXF includes the information for sev-
                         eral machines in the processing chain.
                     •   The format can be used to control machines of the manufacturers Z. Bav-
                         elloni, Intermac, and Forvet.
                     •   The processing machines „understand“ the information provided by the
                         CAM-DXF files. without further programming.
                     •   The information includes all details such as the necessary tools and set-
                         tings, reference points for positioning the suckers, etc.
                     •   CAMDXF can be supported by all machinery manufacturers.
                     It does not replace the CAD/CAM program at the machine, however. This is
                     still required to process the CAM-DXF files.
                     The CAMDXF file can be created in A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) and can be
                     directly sent to production scheduling or to the producer's IT system. No te-
                     dious training of machine operators is required. Through times are reduced
                     and potential sources for errors are eliminated.
                     To write this format by A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) you have to install the
                     corresponding machine driver. The export function is available in menu Ma-
                     chine.

                  Via CAMXML files
                  CAMXML is an xml-based format.
                  Parts of a product (e.g. toughened lites for IG or for laminated glass units) are
                  often purchased. The complete product structure is defined in A+W CAD De-
                  signer (Shapes) but - for obvious reasons - cannot or must not be passed on
                  to the supplier.
                  With the function CAMXML, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) allows to export
                  data of individual BOM elements. These exported elements are fully described
                  and can be imported by the recipient as a new product into another A+W CAD
                  Designer (Shapes) installation. The function is available starting in A+W CAD
                  Designer (Shapes) version 5.02.

                      Select measure

                     1 Open the menu View.

                         •   Enter sizes in mm

                         The three top options define the measure in which numbers are entered:
                         millimeter, inch (fractions, or inch (decimals). The measure of the ruler at

                         If you enter just one number for a size (without mm or ), the measure for

                         to the set measure. Click on mixed sizes to show all sizes with their original

                         Define one measure!

                   Show critical points
                      This setting allows to show (too) pointed angles between segments, (too)
                      short segments, and (too) small inside radii of a contour. The ticked setting
                      is valid.
                  1 Open the menu View.
                  2 In sub-menu Settings click on Show critical points. This offers the following
                    options:
                      •   Mark critical segments in geometry and revision.
                          Critical segments will be shown only in the views Geometry and Revi-
                          sion.
                      •   Mark critical segments in every view.
                          Critical segments will be shown in every view.
                      •   Do not mark critical segments.
                          Critical segments will not be shown.
                  3 Choose one of the displayed options to activate it. A+W CAD Designer
                    (Shapes) now closes the menu. Next time you open the menu, the selected
                    option will be ticked.
                      The file sn.ini defines the point from which on an angle is considered too
                      pointed, or a segment or radius is considered too small. Section User in this
                      file contains four entries which control the display of critical segments:
                      •   MarkInsideRadiusBelow
                          This parameter defines up to which radius arc segments have to
                          marked as critical (the entire segment will be shown in a special colour
                          in this case).
                      •   MarkOutsideAngleAbove
                          This parameter defines the point from which on the external transition
                          angle (outward bend) between segments has to be marked as critical.
                          This is marked by a small arrow pointing at the corresponding spot.




A-510                                                   A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview
Tools                                                                              Fixed Questions




                        •   MarkInsideAngleAbove
                            This parameter defines the point from which on the inside transition an-
                            gle (inward bend) between segments becomes critical. This is marked
                            by a small arrow pointing at the corresponding spot.
                        •   MarkShortSegmentBelow
                            This parameter defines the maximum length up to which a segment has
                            to marked as too short (the entire segment appears in a special colour).


                      Show measuring points
                        This setting allows to restrict the display of measuring points to certain
                        views. Measuring points can be entered in view Points by means of an ap-
                        propriate digitizing tool.
                        These points serve as reference points for the original contour. We do not
                        recommend to change the position of a reference point afterwards. Mea-
                        suring points can be deleted from any view in which they are visible.
                     1 Open the menu View.
                     2 Click in sub-menu Settings on Show measuring points. This offers the fol-
                       lowing options:
                        •   Show measuring points only in view Points:
                            Measuring points will be displayed only in view Points.
                        •   Show measuring points in several views:
                            Measuring points will be shown in the views Points, Geometry, and Re-
                            vision. The last view in which measuring points shall be shown, can be
                            set in the configuration file sn.ini ([View] LastViewToDrawCheckpoints=,
                            default is Revision).
                        •   Show measuring points in all views:
                            Measuring points will appear in all views.


                      Show grid
                        This function allows to show raster points in the drawing. Depending on the
                        display size, raster points are shown per millimeter, centimeter, decimeter,
                        or meter.
                     1 Open the menu View.
                     2 Click in sub-menu Settings on Show raster. The raster is now active. A+W
                       CAD Designer (Shapes) now closes the menu. Next time you open the
                       menu, the selected option will be ticked.
                       To switch off the raster, deselect the option.




A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) Overview                                                           A-511
Fixed Questions                                                                                Tools




                   Background image (opacity)
                     This function allows you to set the visibility and opacity of the background
                     image.
                  1 Open the menu View.
                  2 In sub-menu Settings, click on Background image and then on Opacity.
                  3 Select the required opacity.


                  Segment input for experts
                  This function allows to change the input window for segment input (manual in-
                  put of straight and arc segments).
                   Tutorial, “Input window (D)” on page A-25


                   Enter segments
                  1 Enable Segment input for experts by selecting it in menu View > Settings.
                    A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will tick the entry to show that the function is
                    active.
                  2 Enter segments by defining relative distances, length, angles, etc. Delete
                    the input fields for unknown quantities (there must be no blank). Proceed
                    as follows:
                     •   Straight segment (type 1):
                         Leave the fields for X2 and Y2 blank an enter for dx and dy the relative
                         distance from the segment's start point. Alternatively you can enter X2,
                         leave Y2 blank, and enter dy. A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will calcu-
                         late the line the end point of which has the x coordinate X2 and the Y
                         coordinate Y1+dy.
                     •   Length and angles:
                         You can combine entries when defining length and angles. If you enter
                         dx and dis for instance, A+W CAD Designer (Shapes) will calculate the
                         end point with a horizontal distance dx from the start point, the length of
                         the constructed segment being dis.
                         When you enter angles, you can use <1 to define the angle towards the
                         previous segment or _<_ for the angle to the horizontal axis, both in de-
                         grees and mathematically positive orientation (clockwise being nega-
                         tive, anti-clockwise positive).
                     •   Arcs:
                         The above instructions can be applied to arcs as well. First, define the
                         end point of the arc. After that, you can enter the radius r, the height of
                         the arc h or the length of the arc l to describe the arc.
                  3 Confirm your entry by [OK].
